l1liurxdText: Disease STAR*DTreatment Goals Adverse events Anhedonia                                    Cognitive Symptoms Cognitive Symptoms in Asia Emotional blunting
l1liurxeText:
Emotional blunting is reported by more than half
of patients receiving an antidepressant for the treatment
of MDD1
l1liurxfText:
In an online survey of 1,829 patients treated with
antidepressants†1
l1liurxgText:
of patients receiving
an antidepressant
for the treatment of
MDD reported feeling
emotionally numb1
l1liurxiText:
• 52% reported a reduction in positive feelings1
• 42% stated they cared less about others1
l1liurxkText:
45% of patients experiencing
emotional blunting believe their
antidepressant is affecting their
emotions‡4
l1liurxlText:
39% of patients considered
stopping or have already stopped
their antidepressant because of
its emotional side effects‡4
l1liurxmText:
Only 18% of HCPs thought
that their patients considered
stopping (or had already stopped)
antidepressant because of its
emotional side effects‡4
l1liurxoText: See Brintellix® data
l1liurxpText:
†Antidepressants such as venlafaxine, paroxetine, citalopram, sertraline, escitalopram, tricyclics1
‡Emotional blunting was assessed using the Oxford Depression Questionnaire (ODQ),
which consis ts of three sections. The last section gathers the perceived connection between
antidepres sant use and emotional b lunting.

Brintellix_NewAss_2e55b6604: <font style="font-size: 27px; font-family: '2_TKMNLA+AvenirNextLTPro-Bold';color: rgb(77, 127, 134);">Patients with MDD report emotional blunting to have a greater impact on their lives<sup style="font-size:50%;">†</sup> than HCPs estimate<sup style="font-size:50%;">1</sup></font>
Brintellix_NewAss_20063fd53:
Perspectives of patients with MDD and HCPs in relation to the impact of
emotional blunting1
Brintellix_NewAss_29229594e:
72%

of patients experiencing
emotional blunting in the
acute phase of MDD reported
it to be extremely severe1
Brintellix_NewAss_2bc15b71d:
vs. 30%

estimated by HCPs‡1
Brintellix_NewAss_2dcce6368:
• A high proportion of patients in the acute phase (60-66%) report that emotional blunting has a
significant impact§ on their functioning†1
Brintellix_NewAss_27db7d33f:
†Patient survey item: To what extent do you think your emotional blunting impacts your ability to function effectively a) at work or in studies, b) at home or 
in family life, c) in social life and d) overall, to what extent do you think emotional blunting impacts your overall quality of life? Reported for patients with emotional blunting: patient-reported (acute: n=300).
‡Patient survey item: How severe would you rate the emotional blunting experienced during this phase of depression, using a scale of 1 (not at all severe) to
7 (extremely severe)?
§Significant impact defined as a score of 6–7 on a Likert-type scale from 1 (no impact at all) to 7 (significant impact). Emotional blunting was assessed using
the Oxford Depression Questionnaire (ODQ). Functional capacity in daily life activities was measured with the Functioning Assessment Short Test (FAST).

HCP, healthcare professional; MDD, major depressive disorder.

1. Christensen MC et al. Poster presented at ECNP. P.0100. 2021.
